ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Fundamentals of multivariable calculus, including Stokes' Theorem and Green's Theorem, FTLI, surface integrals and an introduction to vector fields, partial derivatives, and three-dimensional curves and surfaces.

I developed an intuition for how Green's Theorem relates to Stokes' Theorem and the Divergence Theorem. Basically, the advanced theorems all fit together neatly, and it was cool to investigate that in-depth.
I learned a lot of mathematic principle and theorems to attack math problems passed 2 dimensions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Definitely varies with the instructor. If the instructor gives material to practice and explains things well, then this is a very fun class. The videos before class help and practising Ximera on a regular basis is also helpful. 
Weaknesses: Lack of a cheat sheet in exams. Makes absolutely no sense that 115 students get cheat sheets but 120 students don't even though we're dealing with significantly harder topics and taught at a quicker pace.

Tip: watch all the pre-lecture videos every time, including all of the optional ones. You will be tested on all of the content. In class, we do not cover all the content. You can basically teach yourself this entire class from the videos alone and never go to class, and although I did continue to go to class, it felt a bit like a waste of time.

Overall, I felt that this course was rather poorly organized. The pre-lecture videos and what we actually covered in lecture were frequently disconnected which made for a disorienting experience. Additionally, I think the problem sets should be worth far more. Currently, they are only 10% of our grade but make up the vast majority of the work in the class. They should be worth at least 20% and probably more. All other STEM classes I have taken at Yale have a problem set percentage between 20% and 40%.

The course is heavily self taught and therefore relies on the student spending a lot of time out of class/office hours/peer tutors finding a way to teach themselves the material. One result is that there is no unity as some students use a textbook and others use various online resources, which makes going to peers for help or collaboration on psets difficult as everyone understands the content differently. The course is also heavily biased towards formula memorization rather than conceptual understanding, as students who demonstrated understanding on homework and in the classroom failed to pass (or do well on) the exams for lack of a formula sheet and the bias of the exams towards memorization. Allowing students to make a cheat sheet for each exam would greatly improve scores as well as reduce student stress.
Having 2 PSETs due the week before exams was a bit stressful and could be changed. Also, PSET solutions should be posted
Maybe we could add back the extended versions of Green's Theorem and Stokes' Theorem? The strengths are that the course is very organized, with transparency about content and grading.

This course is not very well designed. The lectures and homework are not lined up, and essentially cause students to either decide to be lost at lecture, or not go to lecture and put more responsibility/pressure on themselves to learn independently.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Only if they need it for their major req/pre-req. Or if they're thinking of going into academia or will base a career on STEM. Always a good base to have.
If you need to multivariable calc for your major, then yes. If not, no.
No. If you can, take the ENAS version of multivariable.
Yes, it develops some pretty crucial skills for both theoretical and applied math courses later on. The difficulty is calibrated to be just about the right amount.

No, it is very poorly organized in regards to learning in the classroom and outside the classroom, with a lot of independent learning and very little cohesion between the homework and class. I also do not think there is enough practice in class or examples, normally it is just learning the theorems or titles by name but then not really practicing it in action.
